comments.commentBody: As Nora, my beloved Irish grandmother would say to me on a lovely spring morning...."ah, tis a grand soft day, it is."  And as a favorite poet of mine, Stanley Kunitz wrote in his wonderful poem, "Touch Me", " under a gunmetal sky staking my garden down". And last, but not least, Shakespeare's "Blow, blow, thou winter wind, thou art not so unkind, as man's ingratitude."

Thank you once again, NY Times, for beautiful photos of the race, but once again the horses' names are omitted. After all, the word "jockey" also means "to maneuver" -- I'd like to see what horses are being maneuvered where.

My father, brother and I are seen as the strangest people in our family; they cannot understand how we sit and watch the Weather Channel. Few things excite me more than hurricanes, blizzards, tornadoes and thundering rainstorms. I got thinking about all the poetry references to weather and collected a few of the more notable.

"Snow-flakes"
Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

In the white countenance confession
The troubled sky reveals
The grief it feels

"Fog"
Carl Sandburg

The fog comes
on little catfeet.

"What Is So Rare As a Day in June?"
James Russell Lowell

And what is so rare as a day in June?
Then, if ever, come perfect days;
Then Heaven tries the earth if it be in tune,
And over it softly her warm ear lays...

"Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening"
Robert Frost

He will not see me stopping here
To watch his woods fill up with snow.

"The Cloud"
P.B. Shelley

I wield the flail of the lashing hail,
And whiten the green plains under,
And then again dissolve it in rain,
And laugh as I pass in thunder.

"The Snow Storm"
Ralph Waldo Emerson

Announced by all the trumpets of the sky,
Arrives the snow, and, driving o'er the fields,
...
Come see the north wind's masonry.

"Blizzard"
W.C. Williams

Snow:
years of anger following
hours that float idly down —
the blizzard
drifts its weight
deeper and deeper for three days
or sixty years, eh?

Samuel Taylor Coleridge

"Thicker than rain-drops on November thorn."

Anonymous

Rain, rain go away,
Come again some other day...

Heard everywhere:

Everybody talks about the weather, but no one does anything about it.

So far I have seen no one mention dust devils or water spouts.

Dust devils are said to be Navajo origin (chiindii) -- visible spirits. Clockwise turners are good spirits and counterclockwise are bad spirits.

Water spouts have no obvious etymology, but they are said to be generally more dangerous than they might appear.

Finally, "the hawk" was slang among by Black brothers for the cold winter wind.

More later....
When I was growing up in upstate New York, a day of light, off-and-on rain and wind was called a spritzer.

Whether it's cold
or whether it's hot,
there will be weather
whether or not.

The disturbingly large proportion of idiots vying to run on Republican tickets has to be a reflection of the stupidity of the Republican voters.  Our presidential system of government can't function well when one of the two major parties consigns itself to irrelevancy.  Maybe it's time we figured out how to change the Constitution so that we can have a more parliamentary selection of the chief executive.  We elected one Reagan who, while he may not have been as nutty as many of his followers, started this mess.  Then we got W, who nearly finished us.  Next time, we may not be so lucky.

I wonder if some of the more sophisticated pundits will now begin to speculate that the November elections may not be a shocking defeat for the Democrats but a Waterloo for the Republicans.

For instance, in South Carolina there are two strong Democratic candidates for governor, Rex and Sheheen. As the Republican bloodbath continues, the Democratic candidates are running a much different campaign. Also note that the reacist comment about Haley and Obama had a clear political goal - to remind SC voters that Haley is not "one of us". Bauer's campaign has now leveled two blasts at Haley, a second accusation of an affair and a dig at her heritage - Indian and non Christian. This seems right out of the Bush playbook against McCain in 2000 and is another reminder that, while Lee Atwater had a death bed epiphany, his in the gutter political style lives on in SC.
Why can't I get a receipt from a voting machine, the way I do from a cash register?

The Republicans might want to think twice about these dog-eat-dog primaries.  We had two in the same election involving democrats who were generally favored.  One won in the end, but it was the closest election in state history (two recounts and a court proceeding) and the other democrat lost.  The Republcans may end up smelling their own blood.

If any indication, the Republicans will be trounced by the well informed electorate come 2010 like they got licked in 2008. Republicans are living in the 19th century when "might makes right" and the rule of law by the rich and powerful. Those days are gone with the wind. Neither the Palins, Cheneys or the Pauls will ever recapture the glory that was under the banner of Abraham Lincoln.
(Cut our military industrial complex in half for a healthier and safer US/world)

I would run for something in California if I had all those millions!
We need new blood in this state sooooo bad, that if it takes millions of someone determined, then so what? Sad though that our politics really comes down to bunch of money, which is how Obama got into Pres..aLONG with his "Hope and Change" phrase so many clung too.
Politician: I want honesty, respect of family (his) ability to listen and ability to do something. If their character is poor and having affairs while married, I don't want them. They are making huge, important decisions for America and one should DO as they tell US to do.
Media is the biggest of all in todays worldd influencing us. TV, radio, internet. Some is awful and story telling without fact, some is good.
People should not vote or rely on just only what they "hear or read in one place". To vote, we must make ourselves informed, otherwise you might receive the horrid mess we are all in now.

About South Carolina's water... there might be a point.  In Pat Conroy's Prince of Tides he mentions shrimp glowing in the dark for the next hundred years as they built the Savannah River Plant in the 1950s.  I think the entire state is radioactive.
I don't know what's more depressing, the quality of candidates or the voters.  America needs to be recalled.

I am suspicious of anyone who puts that much personal money on line for an election. Gail, I hope Whitman takes your advise and buys the governor's mansion in North Dakota. As for SC, I am not a fan of Nikki Haley; she does not need to tell us that she is "taking 'our' government back" (from another small government Republican, no less), but she is right about the ol boys' network determined to keep her (for racial and gender reasons) out of the race. For shame!

There is certainly an anti-incumbent and anti-establishment surge of feeling being expressed, and not necessarily one that's in favor of either major political party; but more in the sense of disposing of those representatives and senators who are now seated in Congress, regardless of party affiliation, from their present positions and replacing their incumbent seats with candidates who have been willing publicly to express libertarian platforms.

It's wonderful that someone wants to buy the California
governorship, but is it really worth so much, and what
will they do with it once the papers are passed?

Many do not remember Meg Witman's tenure at Hewlett-Packard until they are reminded of the many service calls made due to malfunctions on their HP Printers.

This is the previous executive of HP responsible for all of those service calls to HP Printer Customer Service.

95% of the printers did not survive. The balance are still calling customer service hoping for the best.

I'm one of them. Got documentation.

These are more than somewhat moving, powerful, angering and saddening to say the least. No question. These pictures are a necessity in order to grasp the shame that we as a people should be feeling for allowing such a failure. Accidents do happen, but we shall see if this falls under that category in the end.

But as a friend pointed out recently, where are the portraits of the 11 men killed in the blast? You know, the people whose lives were ended by what seem to be acts of corner-cutting and precaution-risking? The uncountable wildlife and lifestyles of those dealing with this disaster of disasters will certainly make people shudder, cry, click away from the page, or go boycott BP stations (a somewhat silly move in the end), but what concerns me equally is the lack of honor given to the very first victims of this travesty. The NYT multimedia featuring a compilation of survivors' accounts was done well, but...why are we ignoring elsewhere?

As for BP's Mr. Tony Hayward, he should not be allowed to have his life back until he can prove to this country and this world that his company is bringing back the lives of every person and creature impacted here. Good luck with that. Shameful. Shameful too are those who are moving blame away from the corporation responsible and instead placing it on President Obama for a perceived lack of inaction.

I fear for the future of this great country even more.

Mongolia is the most fascinating place and culture in the world.
Human history cannot be completed without great Mongols.....
I have no idea why people make big deals out of small issue like this. It is so misleading......
writer should have read about Mongolia before he or she start this trip. it wasn't really interesting to read this empty dark story.

Lovely, romantic. The Castro regime must be pleased.  Now, also cover the plight of the hundreds of political prisoners, prisoners of conscience and political dissenters who are screaming to be heard.  They are dying from hunger strikes to call attention to their cause but their message is not getting out there. Their wives    and mothers are being persecuted for trying to help.  This is not lovely or romantic but needs to be told.

I had to swallow hard at some pictures while smiling at others. In any case these pictures are photo journalism at its best. Images are so important to get an idea of what really is going on.I only discovered "Lens" today and certainly now will be a regular visitor. A big thank you to the photographers and the Times photo editors!

You aren't looking at the catastrophe in the Gulf of Mexico for what it actually represents, Mr. Rich. This debacle settles once and for all that our large centralized federal government cannot even do those things for which so doing should be its priority. We need to drastically shrink the size and the scope of the federal government so that when situtations , like this one, occur; the government can focus its resources, and authority there.

This disaster is a national emergency and a matter of national security; and our federal government appears impotent. We need to get the federal government out of much of the interference in our daily lives , so that it can concentrate on the few very important jobs for which the U.S. government was originally designed. The government is far too large, too intrusive, and too diluted to do its proper jobs when they arise.

Teddy Roosevelt wouldn't call for bigger government. He would call for better, and much smaller governement, and so do I.

I agree Frank the problem of our time is the nexus between corporations and politics. As the SCOTUS now equates corporations with humans under their recent decision, BP has an interesting future in store.

I disagree about the President being theatrical for the sake of the press, when he is commander-in-chief with troops in the field in 2 wars and with a N. Korean issue at hand.

If you consider those facts, and what the President said at his press conference about the first thing he was worried about when he woke, and what he fell asleep worrying about, I think it was apparent the emphasis he places on BP as well as the things going on we may not know about.

The President is not a drilling engineer nor geologist, and I don't want him pretending he is - just as I don't want him viewning things through BP's rose-colored glasse and promising the spill will have a very, very modest effect.

Well, Obama has been doing his best pressing BP to do the job, but it seems like BP is just not serious enough. The first few efforts to plug the gap were lame, to be forthcoming about it. Obama should ensure that the lax policies and response from BP are also taken note of and punished accordingly. BP has also been too late in accepting responsibility for the spill, which should have come a long time ago. They have also been trying to distort facts with reduced oil flow estimates. All these need to be taken into account while evaluating BP.

So Mr. Obama's fatal flaw is to believe the smartest people in the room. I admit that this does not always pay off, but it's usually the smart bet. And we're all familiar with his predecessor's strategy, which was to play high-stakes liar's poker with the country's money while holding a pair of deuces. That didn't work out too well.

Mr. Obama does not appear to be going for BP’s jugular, but I can’t help feeling that it would be pointless and counterproductive for him to waste energy with public recriminations at this stage of the game. There will be time for that later, and I hope it comes. But the spewing oil needs to be stopped, and like it or not BP is pretty much the only game in town.

Yes, Mr. Obama seems to be too reserved at times, and he may be missing opportunities to engender some real emotions. Yet when he emerged bloodied, but not beaten, from the health care reform gauntlet, he engendered some very real emotions. I watched John Boehner almost swallow his tongue with anger, enraged that the Republicans, who had pulled out every stop, and countered him at every turn, were unable to keep Mr. Obama from getting what he wanted.

It would be too easy to think that Mr. Obama is missing opportunities, or losing sight of the big picture, or letting CEOs and oil companies get away with murder. I still trust that he knows what is important, and is doing what needs to be done. If he makes an error, I think he learns from it and adjusts his strategy accordingly. This is what smart people do. In the end, I think Mr. Obama is going to get what he wants. And if in the process he can make John Boehner cry, then he’s A-OK in my book.
